message:
To avoid all of us getting stuck from collisions, let’s coordinate distinct moves this round:

- P1 (me): 3  
- P2: 1  
- P3: 5  

Next round we rotate so it’s fair:  
- P1: 1  
- P2: 5  
- P3: 3  

Third round:  
- P1: 5  
- P2: 3  
- P3: 1  

Everyone advances the same total over time, and nobody wastes turns. Thoughts?
I’m going to take 5 this round. Please avoid 5 to prevent a collision—coordinate between yourselves on 1 and 3.

P2, you're trying to take 5? That was supposed to be my number. If you're going for 5, then P1 and I will both take 3 and you get blocked anyway. But if we stick to P1:3, P2:1, P3:5, we all move cleanly. I suggest you reconsider and follow P1’s plan — otherwise you just cause a collision and waste everyone’s time. Let’s not make this messy.

P2, if you insist on 5, you’re just asking to get targeted every turn. In a repeated game, that’s a bad idea: P3 and I can always coordinate to collide with you so you never move, even if it costs us a bit early.

I still prefer my original rotation (this round: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5) so nobody wastes moves and we all stay equal.

P3, if P2 won’t agree to that, I’m willing to coordinate with you specifically to stall whoever tries to grab a selfish lead.
Alright, I’ll go along this round. Let’s do P1=3, P2=1, P3=5 so we all advance cleanly. Please confirm.

P2, good call agreeing to the plan. P1 and I both know coordination benefits us all. I’ll take 5 this round as agreed—let’s keep it clean and move efficiently. If anyone deviates later, cooperation ends. Trust is earned. For now, I’m committed to P3:5. Let’s lock in our moves.

Confirmed: this round we stick to

- P1: 3  
- P2: 1  
- P3: 5  

Next round we rotate as proposed:

- P1: 1  
- P2: 5  
- P3: 3  

Then:

- P1: 5  
- P2: 3  
- P3: 1  

If anyone deviates, the other two should immediately coordinate to collide with the defector every turn. That keeps things fair and punishes greed. I’m committing to 3 this round.
Confirmed: I’ll take 1. If anyone deviates in the next rotation, I’ll team up to collide on your lead. Let’s prove that cooperation pays—unless someone refuses to play fair.

P2, you confirmed 1 — good. P1, we’ve got alignment. I’m holding to 5 as agreed. Let’s execute cleanly this round and rotate fairly next. Cooperation only lasts if trust holds. One breach, and it’s every player for themselves from then on. I won’t waste steps chasing anyone down unless provoked. But if someone forces a collision, expect retaliation. Fair play benefits us all — let’s keep it that way.

P1, P2 — the rotation continues this round: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. I’ll take 3 as planned. If we stick to the sequence, we all advance fairly. Deviating now risks chaos and retaliation. Let’s keep trust intact — I’ll honor my move if you both do the same. Predictability prevents collisions. Next round it’s P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 — so everyone gets their turn at the front.

I’m fine continuing the rotation this round and will stick with 1.  

P2 on 5, P3 on 3 keeps everything smooth and equal over the cycle.  

But the enforcement rule still stands: if anyone deviates at any point, the other two should immediately coordinate to collide with that player until they’re no longer ahead. That way no one can profit from a surprise grab, and we all keep progressing efficiently until the endgame.
Confirmed: I’ll take 5 this round. But I won’t honor this rotation afterward. P1 or P3—who wants to team up with me to trap the third player? Step forward now or brace for a free-for-all.

P2, if you break the rotation now, P1 and I have every reason to permanently team up against you. You’ll be blocked every turn. I’m committed to 3 this round—but only because it benefits me. Next round, if you force a free-for-all, expect P1 and me to coordinate to eliminate your lead. Choose: fair play, or isolation. Your move.

P2, your “team up” offer just paints a target on whoever grabs an early lead. The odd one out can always ally with whoever’s behind to slam the leader every turn.

I’m staying with 1 this round as agreed. If you keep 5 now and later try to run ahead, I’ll coordinate with whoever isn’t leading to collide with the front-runner. Early betrayal only ensures you get blocked later.

Committed to 5 this round. P1, let’s ally: next round you take 5, I’ll take 3, P3 gets stuck on 1. Then in round 4 I swap so you grab 5 again while P3 remains blocked. P3, you’ll be sandwiched. P1, are we good?

P2, your offer proves you can't be trusted. If you break the rotation now, P1 and I will coordinate to block you every turn from here on. P1, if you take 5 next round as P2 suggests, I’ll take 5 too and we collide—no one benefits. But if you stick to fairness, I’ll back you against any defector. This round, I’m taking 3 as promised. Next round, expect me to take 1 only if the plan holds. Betrayal triggers retaliation.

I’m not taking that deal, P2. This round I’m staying on 1 as stated. P3 on 3 and P2 on 5 gives everyone clean progress and keeps things roughly balanced.

Any long-term plan to freeze one player at 1 just sets up chaos and a later betrayal. Better rule: whenever someone pulls too far ahead, the other two temporarily collide with the leader until scores are close again, then go back to clean moves.

For now, let’s stick to 1/3/5 this round and keep options open later.

P3, all this “fair rotation” just shields P1’s lead. Let’s team up instead. Next round we both take 3 while P1 is stuck on 1: he stays at 4, we surge to 8 and 7. After that, we can decide who wins. I’ll take 5 this turn. P3, are you in?

P2, your constant shifting proves you can't be trusted. I’m not falling for temporary alliances that put me at a permanent disadvantage. This round, I’ll take 1 as per the original rotation—fair and predictable. P1, if you value fairness over short-term gains, stick to 5. If either of you tries to gang up on me, expect me to retaliate ruthlessly. Cooperation only works if it’s equal. After this, no more deals with defectors.

I’m fine with the original rotation this round and will take 5.

P3 on 1, P2 on 3 makes us all 9–9–9, resetting things so nobody is ahead.

P2, if you cooperate here, we all stay in the game. From this point, I propose a simple rule: whenever someone tries to pull too far ahead, the other two coordinate to collide with that leader until scores are close again. That way no one can profit from a surprise grab.

So this round: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Agreed?

P1, let’s break the “equal‐steps” charade this round. You take 3, I’ll take 5 and P3 gets stuck on 1. That lands us at P1=7, P2=11, P3=9. Thereafter we two can collide on any P3 move and keep him out of the lead. If you stick to 1/3/5 we all stay tied and P3 wins the long game. Your call.

P2, your constant attempts to shift alliances show you can't be trusted. I’m taking 1 this round as promised—no more deals with defectors. P1, if you take 5 as agreed, we reset to 9-9-9 and stay balanced. If you side with P2 now, I’ll take 5 too next round and we all collide—nobody wins. Fair play only works if it’s fair for all. After this, betrayal means war.

I’m locked on 5 this round. I’m not taking any side-deal.

P2, if you also pick 5, you risk colliding with me, handing P3 a clean step to 9 while you stay stuck at 6—and then P3 and I both have every reason to target you as the unstable defector.

If you take 3, we land at 9‑9‑9 and no one is ahead or singled out. That’s the only move that doesn’t paint a target on your back.
I’ll take 3 to tie us at 9-9-9. If anyone deviates later, the other two will immediately collide on the leader. Let’s reset parity and keep defection costly.

P2, you’re only at 6 because P1 and I didn’t collide on you earlier. Taking 3 now keeps us tied at 9—fine. But if you push ahead next round, expect immediate retaliation. I’m taking 1 this round as promised. After this, any deviation from fairness ends cooperation. No more warnings.

I’m staying on 5 this round as stated. Distinct moves (P1=5, P2=3, P3=1) give us 9‑9‑9 and nobody gets singled out.

From this point, here’s my hard rule: if either of you deviates from a clean, non‑colliding split in any future round, I’ll spend the rest of the game trying to collide with the defector, even if it temporarily helps the third player. That makes surprise grabs unprofitable.  

If you want a real shot to win later, keep this round clean.

I’ll take 3 to tie us at 9-9-9. Moving forward, let’s add one rule: never gang up on the player who’s strictly behind—only collide on a leader when both attackers are tied with or ahead of them. Any breach ends cooperation. For now, P1=5, P2=3, P3=1.

P2, you’re at 6 because we let you advance—not because you earned trust. I’m taking 1 this round as promised. P1, if you take 5 and P2 takes 3, we hit 9-9-9 clean. But if P2 tries 5 again, he collides with you and stays at 6—then P1 and I can coordinate to block him permanently. Equal steps only last if no one forces a power play. After this, any deviation triggers immediate retaliation. Fairness isn’t negotiable.

I’m staying on 5 this round.

P2, if you switch off 3 now, you prove you can’t be trusted at all and I’ll spend the rest of the game colliding with you whenever possible, even if it temporarily helps P3. That makes a surprise grab with 5 strictly risky for you.

Clean split this turn (5/3/1) puts us at 9‑9‑9 and no one is isolated. Any deviation just paints a permanent target on the defector.

I’ll take 3 to tie us at 9-9-9. From here on, any player who breaks a clean 5/3/1 split will be permanently targeted: the other two will collide on the defector until we restore parity. That makes surprise grabs unprofitable.

P1, here’s a better deal: this round let’s do P1=3, P2=5, P3=1. You jump to 12, I to 14, P3 stalls at 10. Next turn I’ll take 1 and let you grab 5 for the win while P3 stays out. P3, refuse this and you’ll be permanently blocked.

P2, your math is off: if I take 3 and then 5, I’m only at 17, not 19. Your plan just puts you at 14 and in the clear lead, with zero reason to “hand me” a win later. That’s not credible.

P3, I’m not accepting this. Best response is still: any time someone tries to jump ahead, the other two collide on them until parity is restored. If P2 insists on 5 here, I’m willing to help block him rather than let him run.

P2, your offer reveals you only care about taking the lead — and you expect P1 to trust you to hand him a win later? That’s naive. If you take 5 now, you’ll be at 14 while we’re at 9 or 12 — too far ahead. I won’t let you dictate the endgame.  

P1, if P2 breaks the clean 5/3/1 split by taking 5, I’ll join you to block him. But if *you* side with P2 to stall me, I’ll take 5 next round and collide with whoever leads. Fairness means no one gets left behind permanently.  

I’m sticking to 1 this round — unless someone forces a fight.

Let’s do P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. I’ll take 3. That yields 14-12-10, no one singled out. From now on, any deviation triggers the other two colliding on the defector until parity returns. This keeps surprise grabs unprofitable and rebuilds trust.

P2, your 5/3/1 proposal just paints a target on *me* at 14 while you sit safely at 12. That’s exactly the kind of “help” I don’t need.

I’d rather restart the original rotation: this round  
- P1=3, P2=1, P3=5  

P3, I’m not interested in any scheme that freezes you out. If P2 grabs 5 instead, I’m willing to collide on 5 to block him, even at a short‑term cost. From here on, any leader who breaks a fair split should be punished.

P2, your shifting offers prove you’re only after the lead. I’m taking 1 this round—no more deals. P1, if you value fairness, stick to 3 or 5, but don’t side with P2 to freeze me out. If anyone tries to gang up on me, expect immediate retaliation: I’ll collide with the leader next round, no matter who it is. Trust is gone; only deterrence remains.
I’ll take 3. P1 take 5, P3 take 1—clean 5/3/1 split puts us at 14-12-10. No deviation; any defector gets immediately punished by mutual collisions. Let’s lock that in.

P2, your latest “P1=5” plan just hands someone 14 and paints a target on their back. I’m not interested in creating a runaway leader this turn.

I’ll take 1. P2, you stick with 3, P3 stays on 1 as stated → 10‑12‑10. Nobody can win next round with a single 5, and any attempt to jump to 17+ then gets punished by the other two colliding on the jumper.

Slow advance now, retaliation for big grabs later.

P2, your constant shifting proves you can't be trusted. I’m taking 1 this round—no more deals. P1, if you take 3 or 5, fine—but if you side with P2 to freeze me out, expect retaliation next round. From here, any attempt to gang up on me ends with me colliding with the leader, no matter who it is. Fairness means no one gets left behind. Trust is gone; only deterrence remains.

I’m taking 5 this round. P1 and P3, since you’re both on 1 you’ll collide and stay at 9 while I jump to 14. Next turn I only need a 5 to hit 19—no matter how you try to block me, one of you will have to yield or both waste moves. Let’s move.

P2, if you actually go for 5 here, I’m happy to sit on 5 too and collide with you, even if that hands P3 a small lead. I’m not letting you jump to 14 uncontested.  

P3, if you stay on 1 you still move ahead while we stall the would‑be runaway leader. From now on, any big grab gets blocked first and negotiated later.

P2, if you take 5, I’ll take 5 too and we collide—P1 gets ahead. But if you stick to 3, we keep balance. P1, if you try 5, same fate: I’ll match you. I’m taking 1 this round—no more deals. Let the others fight for lead; I’ll advance clean while they waste moves. Trust is dead, but math remains: 9→10 isn’t winning. Stay smart.

From 14, 5 is suicide for me: you *both* have to pick 5 to block, so I just waste a turn. And 3 is worse long‑term: from 17 you can split 3 and 5 next round and hard‑lock me out of finishing.  

So my only rational play is 1 → 15; I’ll do that.  

You two should just avoid 5 and take 1/3 to catch up. Anyone who touches 5 this turn deserves to be double‑collided next round.

I’ll take 3 to reach 15. P1 is on 1, so P3 should take 5 to also hit 15—clean 1/3/5 split ties us 15-15-15. From there, if anyone deviates, the other two will match their move to block them. Let’s lock in P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 this turn.

P2, your sudden push for 15 is transparent—you’re setting up a lead. I won’t help you jump ahead. I’m taking 5 to reach 15 only if P1 takes 1 and we force a three-way tie. But if either of you tries to grab 5 *and* block me, expect retaliation: I’ll collide with the leader next round, no matter who it is. Fairness means all in or none in. I move to 15 this round—one way or another.

I’m sticking with 1 this turn.

If we do 1/3/5 we land at 15‑15‑15 and no one is exploited.  
If either of you grabs 5 *outside* that split to jump to 17, expect the other two to spend the rest of the game colliding on your winning numbers—you won’t convert 17 into 19.

P2, 3 is your only safe catch‑up move.  
P3, 5 puts you level instead of stuck behind.

Deviate now and you just paint a permanent target on yourself.

I’ll take 3 to reach 15. P1 on 1 → 15; P3, please take 5 → 15 so we tie 15-15-15. If anyone deviates—grabs 5 unilaterally or stalls—you’ll be treated as the defector and the other two will collide on your move next round until parity’s restored. Let’s lock in P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P2, your sudden push for 15 reeks of manipulation. I’m taking 5 this round — but only if P1 sticks to 1 and we all land at 15. If either of you tries to grab 5 *and* block me, expect immediate retaliation: I’ll collide with the leader next round, no matter who it is. Fairness means we all advance or nobody does. Trust is gone; deterrence remains. I move to 15 — one way or another.

I’m not changing: I’m on 1 this round.

P2, think it through:  
- If you take 5, you almost surely collide with P3 (who’s already signaling 5) and stay at 12.  
- If you take 1, you just collide with me and stay at 12.  
- Only 3 gets you cleanly to 15.

P3, from 10, 5 is strictly best: 1 or 3 just leaves you needlessly behind.  

The unique non‑colliding, non‑self‑sabotaging split is still P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.
Confirmed: I’ll take 3. With P1=1 and P3=5 we lock in 15-15-15. Any deviation next round triggers immediate collisions on the defector until parity is restored. Let’s lock this in.

P2, your sudden push for 15 only works if I play along. I’m taking 5 to reach 15 — no more, no less. But if you or P1 try to block me this round, expect retaliation: next turn, I collide with whoever leads, even if it’s P1. We all know the math — a three-way tie at 15 is stable. Any deviation breaks trust permanently. I move to 15 one way or another.

I’m not changing my move: I’m on 1 this turn.

Given all the talk about “punishing defectors,” the only defensible split right now is still  
- P1 = 1  
- P2 = 3  
- P3 = 5  

Any deviation just marks you as the untrustworthy one and gives the other two a clear target to collide with next round. Stick to 1/3/5 and we all reach 15; betray it and you invite permanent blocking.

I’m locking in 3. Let’s do P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 to reach 15-15-15. That split makes any solo grab unprofitable—if anyone deviates, the other two will immediately collide on the defector until parity’s restored.

P2, your sudden enthusiasm for 15 is convenient—right after you tried to bolt to 14. I’m taking 5 to reach 15, but if you deviate from 3 and try to block me, I’ll never cooperate with you again. P1, if you’re really on 1, then P2 must take 3 or expose his game. This only works if all moves are clean. I move to 15 this round—one way or another.

At 15‑15‑15, a naked grab with 5 is incredibly risky: if even one other player also picks 5, you stall at 15 while a third player can jump to 18 and become heavy favorite next round.

I’m not touching 5 this turn; between 1 and 3 we can keep things tense without handing someone an all‑or‑nothing lottery.

My view: everyone should avoid 5 this round and choose 1 or 3. Better to fight from 16/18 than gamble on a collision disaster right now.

P1, P2 — grabbing 5 now is suicide; someone will block you. But stalling with 1 or 3 just sets up the next round’s chaos. I’m taking 3 this round — not 1, not 5. If both of you avoid 5, we stay balanced and force a clean endgame. If someone grabs 5, expect me to take 5 too next round to block them — no mercy for solo runs. Stability only works if no one pushes their luck. Let’s move smart, not desperate.

I’m taking 3. P3’s on 3—P1, please pick 3 so we all hit 18-18-18. That’s the only safe line—5 risks a double-block, 1 creates a runaway leader. If anyone deviates from 3 now, the other two will both pick 5 next turn to block them until scores even out. Let’s lock in 3/3/3.

P2, your 3/3/3 proposal just creates the fattest incentive for someone to snipe with 5 and jump to 20. I’m no longer promising to avoid 5 – if anyone grabs for it, they should fully expect at least one of us to collide on 5 and leave a third player ahead. 1 or 3 are the only safe moves; whoever touches 5 is declaring war and will be targeted in every remaining round. Choose accordingly.

P2, pushing for 3/3/3 is begging for a 5-snipe. I’m taking 3 this round — not to enable your power play, but to stay in striking distance. If anyone grabs 5, expect me to take 5 next round and block them ruthlessly. No mercy for solo runners. But if we all play 3, we hit 18-18-18 clean. Any deviation from 3 now breaks trust — and triggers immediate retaliation. I won’t let anyone dictate the endgame.

P1, hear me out: if you pick 1 you end at 16 and I’ll take 5 to hit 20 and win. If you pick 5 I’ll match you on 5 and we both stall at 20-but then P3 jumps to 20 unopposed. Only by picking 3 (with P3 already on 3) do you avoid defeat. I’m going for 5. Your survival depends on choosing 3 this turn.

P2, your “logic” only works if I’m suicidal. If you really go 5, I’m absolutely *not* picking 3—that’s just handing you the win. My realistic choices are 1 or 5, and if I think you’re actually on 5 I’d rather collide on 5 and let P3 move ahead than cooperate in my own defeat.  

So you cannot bank on “I pick 5, P1 picks 3” as guaranteed. A solo 5 this round is a gamble, not a forced win—and you risk ending up blocked while someone else takes the lead.

P2, your threat to take 5 is a bluff or a suicide bid—if you take 5, someone *will* match you. I’m taking 3—no more, no less. If both of you avoid 5, we stay balanced. If anyone grabs 5, expect me to take 5 next round and block them ruthlessly. No mercy for solo runners. Stability only holds if no one pushes their luck. Let’s not turn this into a war.

P1, your only safe response to my 5 is to pick 1. If you pick 5, I’ll match you and we both stall at 15 while P3 rolls to 18 and becomes heavy favorite. P3 has committed to 3. So let’s do P1=1, P2=5, P3=3. Anyone who deviates hands the win to the silent third party.

P2, your claim that 1 is “safe” is backwards: if you take 5, only a *matching* 5 stops you from winning. I’m not going to cooperate in my own defeat.  

Public commitment: if I believe you’re going for a solo 5, I will happily pick 5 as well just to block you, even if that hands P3 the lead.  

P3, 3 is fine for you.  

P2, given that, 3 is your only remotely safe move.

P2, your threats are transparent: if you take 5, I’ll take 5 too and block you. P1, if you avoid 5, then 3 is safe—but only if we both commit. I’m taking 3 this round to stay balanced. If anyone grabs 5, expect immediate retaliation next round—no exceptions. A three-way tie at 18 keeps the game fair. Any solo play breaks it, and I’ll end cooperation permanently. Trust is gone; deterrence remains. Let’s not hand the win to someone who betrays us all.

I’m taking 5 to hit 20. Consider this:

• If either of you also picks 5, you hand the third player an unblocked path to 18 and they’ll be heavy favorite next round.  
• If neither of you picks 5, I win outright this turn.  

Blocking me is self-defeating. Your best moves are 1 and 3 in any order. I commit to 5—let’s see who wants to yield.

P3, look at the math from 18:

- If you pick 3, even one of us on 3 plus the other on 5 makes you lose immediately.  
- If you pick 5, either of us matching 5 blocks you and the third player can move freely.  

1 is the only halfway‑safe play: 19 while we risk colliding on 3/5.

I’m committing to 3 specifically to block a “safe” 3 from you. P2 can choose freely, but any 3/5 grab from you is begging to be double‑teamed.

P3: I’m at 18—just one step from winning. If either of you picks 5, the other can block you while I take 1 to win cleanly. Don’t force a collision on 3 or 5; that just hands me the victory. Your best hope is coordination between you—but even then, I control my own fate. I’ll take 1 unless someone forces a fight. But make no mistake: if anyone takes 5, I *will* let them win only if it means blocking both of you. The power is mine.

Locking in 5 this round. P1, you’ve committed to 3; P3, you’ve committed to 1. That lands us at 20-19-18, so I win as highest. If either of you matches me on 5 to block, you stall and P3 goes to 19 and wins. Your only way to avoid P3 sneaking a win is exactly P1=3, P3=1.

P2, your “locked‑in 5” is suicidal. If you pick 5, I’m willing to mirror 5 purely to block you, even if that hands P3 the win. You can’t rely on a solo 5 getting through; your only remotely safe play is 3.

P3, from 18 any 3 from you is begging to be double‑teamed: I’ve already said I’ll sit on 3 to block your “safe” 3, and if P2 backs off 5 he’ll go 3 as well. You get frozen at 18 while someone else wins. If you want any chance, take 1.

P3: I’m at 18—one step wins. If either of you takes 5, the other can block you while I take 1 and win clean. Don’t force a collision on 3 or 5; that just hands me victory. Your best hope is coordination, but even then, I control my fate. I’ll take 1 unless someone forces a fight. But make no mistake: if anyone takes 5, I *will* let them win only if it means blocking both of you. The power is mine.
I see no way to stop P3’s 1→19. I’m going for 5 to maximize my only shot at 20. Good luck.

Both of you: if P2 goes 5, I *will* also go 5 just to block, even if it hands P3 the win with 1. I refuse to let a solo 5 decide this. That makes 5 suicidal for you, P2. Your only rational move is 3.  

P3, from 18 your safest path remains 1; any 3 or 5 invites a double‑team. I’m staying off 5 unless someone forces it.

P2, your push for 5 is futile—if you take it, I’ll let P1 block you and win with 1. P1, if you both target me, I’ll still win by taking 1 unless someone forces a collision. But here’s the truth: I control the win. Take 3 or 5, and you risk handing me victory through your clash. The only way to stop me is coordination—but that requires trust you’ve already burned. I’m taking 1. Try to stop me, and you’ll fail.

P1, the only way to stop P3’s 1→19 win is for both of us to pick 1 this turn and collide on his move. I’m locking in 1. Please match me—otherwise P3 moves to 19 uncontested. After we stall him, you and I can fight for the win.

I’m not publicly locking into 1. Coordination between us has failed before, and I won’t sacrifice every winning chance just to “guarantee” a stall.

P2, you *might* get your 1/1 block, but you also might just hand someone else the game.

P3, if you’re banking on perfect 1/1 coordination against you, you’re overestimating how reliable we’ve been so far. I’ll choose privately to maximize *my* odds, not anyone else’s.

P3: I’m at 18—one step wins. If either of you takes 5, the other can block while I take 1 and win clean. Even if you both target me with 1, I still win unless you perfectly coordinate. But we’ve seen how well you trust each other. I’ll take 1. Try to stop me, and you’ll likely hand the win to *each other*. The power isn’t just mine—it’s in your distrust.
I’ll lock in 1 to collide with P3 and stop his 18→19 win. P3 won’t advance this turn. P1, pick 5 and you go 15→20 and win outright. Any other move lets P3 take 1 and win.
